Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award: Development of New Halide-based Rare-Earth Scintillators

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing research programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at her home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Hampton University has potential impact in the areas of high energy physics, homeland security, and nuclear medicine through the development of new halide-based rare-earth detectors. The results of this project will add new knowledge on the optical, structural, electronic, and scintillation properties of the proposed materials, impacting the development of efficient radiation sensors. Every year, two undergraduate students will be directly involved in the research. Outreach activities are planned to local K-12 schools and community colleges.

Scintillators have attracted enormous interest over the last decade for a wide range of applications such as homeland security, monitoring nuclear materials, X-ray imaging screens, high-energy particle physics experiments, industrial inspections, and gas exploration. Scintillators are materials that are capable of converting high energy radiation such as X-rays or gamma rays to visible light. The objective of this research is to develop new halide-based rare-earth scintillator materials. Divalent europium (Eu2+) doped lead halide based binary compounds such as PbCl2, PbBr2, PbI2 will be used as scintillation crystals. The work will also involve the comparison of high performing halide scintillators including Eu2+:SrI2 and Eu2+:BaI2 for better understanding the optical properties and the scintillation mechanisms. Spectroscopic characterization and the structural and electronic properties of Eu2+ doped lead halides will be evaluated as potential scintillator materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The development of scintillator materials for nuclear radiation detection continues to be of great current interest for a wide range of applications such as homeland security, monitoring nuclear materials, X-ray imaging screens, high-energy particle physics experiments, industrial inspections and gas exploration. Scintillators are materials that are capable of converting high energy radiation (X-rays or gamm-rays) to ultra-violet or visible light. An important class of scintillators is based on rare-earth doped halide crystals, which have shown good performance in terms of high light outputs, fast response, and good energy resolution for material identification. In this research project new materials based on rare earth doped binary and ternary lead halide crystals were investigated for possible applications in nuclear radiation detection. Many halide based scintillator materials are strongly hygroscopic, which puts stringent demands on their handling and processing for use in detectors. On the contrary, lead halide based crystals offer the advantage of being non-hygroscopic and can be used under atmospheric conditions without additional protection. Several rare earth ions (Ce3+, Pr3+, Eu2+) doped lead halide based crystals (e.g. PbCl2, KPb2Cl5, PbBr2, KPb2Br5) were prepared during the course of this project and investigated for their optical properties relevant for scintillator applications. The material preparation showed that several purification methods (e.g. zone-refinement, chlorination/bromination) have to be applied to grow single crystal binary and ternary lead halides. The obtained transmission and absorption spectra demonstrated the successful incorporation of Ce3+, Pr3+, and Eu2+ ions in the investigated lead halide crystals. The most promising crystal identified for possible scintillator applications was Ce3+ doped potassium lead chloride, KPb2Cl5, whcih exhibited visible emission under ultra-violet optical excitation. The overall light output and performance, however, was limited by residual impurities and low overall crystal quality.

Broader Impact

Besides providing new insight and knowledge on lead halide based scinitillator materials, the project offered new education and research training opportunities in materials science, optical spectroscopy, and nuclear radiaton detectors for several students from underrepresented minority groups. Furthermore, the project offered new STEM outreach opportunities for students from local schools. Several K-12 students visited Hampton University and were exposed to hands-on laboratory demonstrations in general science, materials, and optical spectroscopy.
